description:
From Middle English wesele, from Old English weosule, from Proto-West Germanic *wisulā, from Proto-Germanic *wisulǭ. 
The verb is from c. 1900, from the supposed cunningness of the weasel.

entries.meaning: Any of the carnivorous mammals of the genus Mustela, having a slender body, a long tail and usually a light brown upper coat and light-coloured belly.
The taxonomic family Mustelidae is also called the weasel family.
A devious or sneaky person or animal.

A type of yarn winder used for counting the yardage of handspun yarn. It most commonly has a wooden peg or dowel that pops up from the gearing mechanism after a certain number of yards have been wound onto the winder.

verbs.description: weasel (third-person singular simple present weasels, present participle weaseling or weaselling, simple past and past participle weaseled or weaselled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To achieve by clever or devious means.
examples: Prisoners are notorious for weaseling day passes to get out of lockup […] .

entries.meaning: (transitive or reflexive) To gain something for oneself by clever or devious means.
(intransitive) To engage in clever or devious behavior.
